elements.content: Four helical coordination polymers, [Cd(anti-bime)(1,3-pda)] n (1), [Cd(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n (2), [Co(anti-bime)(1,2-pda)] n (3), and [Co(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n (4), have been solvothermally prepared by the assembly of mixed flexible ligands, bime and 1,3-H2pda, 1,4-H2pda, 1,2-H2pda with Cd(NO3)2·4H2O and Co(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively (bime = 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)ethane, 1,3-H2pda = 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid, 1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid, 1,2-H2pda = 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that all of the complexes possess helical structures owing to the use of mixed flexible ligands; the conformations of flexible bime are entirely different, anti-bime occurs in 1 and 3, while gauche-bime occurs in 2 and 4. The fluorescent properties of 1 and 2 suggest that the intense broad photoluminescence emission at 387 nm for 1 and 389 nm for 2, 3, and 4 exhibit similar weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co2+ centers.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that all of the complexes possess helical structures owing to the use of mixed flexible ligands; the conformations of flexible bime are entirely different, anti-bime occurs in 1 and 3, while gauche-bime occurs in 2 and 4. The fluorescent properties of 1 and 2 suggest that the intense broad photoluminescence emission at 387 nm for 1 and 389 nm for 2, 3, and 4 exhibit similar weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the Co2+ centers.

elements.content: The solvothermal reactions of 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)ethane (bime), 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid (1,3-H2pda), 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (1,4-H2pda), 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid (1,2-H2pda) with different metal ions gave rise to four novel helical coordination polymers. The presence of different orientations of carboxylate groups in 1,3-H2pda, 1,4-H2pda, and 1,2-H2pda play a crucial role in the conformational preference of bime in the four complexes.

The presence of different orientations of carboxylate groups in 1,3-H2pda, 1,4-H2pda, and 1,2-H2pda play a crucial role in the conformational preference of bime in the four complexes.

elements.content: The preparation and exploration of metal−organic frameworks based on the self-assembly process are of great interest in crystal engineering, supramolecular chemistry, and material science, which in principle not only can provide tunable architectures and intriguing topologies, but also is helpful for seeking their potential application in gas absorption, molecular recognition, and catalysis. In this respect, the judicious choice of the appropriate metal ions and tailor-made organic precursors is the dominating factor for the construction of well-defined frameworks. As is well-known, the formation of coordination polymers from rigid ligands may be more easily predicted and controlled than those from flexible ligands owing to the predefined and programmable information in the rigid ligands. Despite the lack of predictability and tunability, the syntheses and preparation of the classes of metal−organic compounds from the flexible multidentate ligands have also been developed. The flexibility and conformational freedom of these ligands favor the possibility of generating interesting frameworks and supramolecular isomers, in which the conformational separation or molecular self-recognition of ligands can be further exploited. For example, flexible N/O-donor ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, or their analogues can induce different “supramolecular isomers”, where the conformational separation of the ligands (gauche/anti or cis/trans) occurred. Besides the natural flexibility of the original ligands, other subtle factors, such as coordination geometries of metal ions, reaction conditions, ancillary ligands, guest molecules, and temperature, are also important for the induction of ligand conformation in metal−organic frameworks. Therefore, the search for methods of controlling and separating conformation of flexible ligands is still one of the most challenging issues.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The preparation and exploration of metal-organic frameworks based on the self-assembly process are of great interest in crystal engineering, supramolecular chemistry, and material science, which in principle not only can provide tunable architectures and intriguing topologies, but also is helpful for seeking their potential application in gas absorption, molecular recognition, and catalysis. In this respect, the judicious choice of the appropriate metal ions and tailor-made organic precursors is the dominating factor for the construction of well-defined frameworks. As is well-known, the formation of coordination polymers from rigid ligands may be more easily predicted and controlled than those from flexible ligands owing to the predefined and programmable information in the rigid ligands. Despite the lack of predictability and tunability, the syntheses and preparation of the classes of metal-organic compounds from the flexible multidentate ligands have also been developed. The flexibility and conformational freedom of these ligands favor the possibility of generating interesting frameworks and supramolecular isomers, in which the conformational separation or molecular self-recognition of ligands can be further exploited. For example, flexible N/O-donor ligands, such as 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid, or their analogues can induce different "supramolecular isomers", where the conformational separation of the ligands (gauche/anti or cis/trans) occurred. Besides the natural flexibility of the original ligands, other subtle factors, such as coordination geometries of metal ions, reaction conditions, ancillary ligands, guest molecules, and temperature, are also important for the induction of ligand conformation in metal-organic frameworks. Therefore, the search for methods of controlling and separating conformation of flexible ligands is still one of the most challenging issues.

elements.content: Di- or multitopic carboxylates as anionic ligands have been widely investigated and have resulted in various neutral metal−organic frameworks owing to their interesting characteristics including strong coordination ability, rich coordination modes of carboxylate groups, different organic skeletons of carboxylate linkers, abundant hydrogen-bonding interactions, and the decrease of the effect of counterions on the products. In particular, the different positions of carboxylate groups situated in the organic skeletons may connect metal ions in different directions and distances into extended networks. However, the research about the effect of the orientation of carboxylate groups in the organic skeletons on the conformation of the flexible ligands remains less explored.
elements.clean_text: Di- or multitopic carboxylates as anionic ligands have been widely investigated and have resulted in various neutral metal-organic frameworks owing to their interesting characteristics including strong coordination ability, rich coordination modes of carboxylate groups, different organic skeletons of carboxylate linkers, abundant hydrogen-bonding interactions, and the decrease of the effect of counterions on the products. In particular, the different positions of carboxylate groups situated in the organic skeletons may connect metal ions in different directions and distances into extended networks. However, the research about the effect of the orientation of carboxylate groups in the organic skeletons on the conformation of the flexible ligands remains less explored.

elements.content: As an analogue of well-investigated dipyridyl 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)ethane (bime) bearing two imidazolyl coordination groups possesses gauche and anti conformations (Scheme ). Using this ligand and rigid dicarboxylate ligands, we have successfully synthesized several metal−organic complexes, where single or mixed conformations of bime ligands were exhibited, and have studied the effect of the coexistent neutral ligands, electronic and steric properties of the rigid dicarboxylate ligands as well as metal ions on bime conformational isomerism, crystal structures, and properties. As a continuation of our research, herein we wish to report the syntheses, crystal structures, and characterizations of two cadmium and two cobalt helical coordination polymers from the mixed flexible ligands, [Cd(anti-bime)(1,3-pda)] n (1), [Cd(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n (2), [Co(anti-bime)(1,2-pda)] n (3), and [Co(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n (4) (1,3-H2pda = 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid, 1,4-H2pda = 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid, 1,2-H2pda = 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid) in which the conformations of bime are deeply affected by the orientation of carboxylate groups in 1,3-H2pda, 1,4-H2pda, and 1,2-H2pda. The four complexes have been well characterized by IR spectra, elemental analysis, X-ray powder diffraction, and single X-ray diffraction analysis. The corresponding fluorescent and magnetic properties were also discussed.

Using this ligand and rigid dicarboxylate ligands, we have successfully synthesized several metal-organic complexes, where single or mixed conformations of bime ligands were exhibited, and have studied the effect of the coexistent neutral ligands, electronic and steric properties of the rigid dicarboxylate ligands as well as metal ions on bime conformational isomerism, crystal structures, and properties. The four complexes have been well characterized by IR spectra, elemental analysis, X-ray powder diffraction, and single X-ray diffraction analysis. The corresponding fluorescent and magnetic properties were also discussed.

elements.content: All the reagents were commercially available and used as purchased except that 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)ethane was synthesized according to the literature method. IR spectra as KBr pellets were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction measurements were recorded on a RIGAKU DMAX2500PC diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation. Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL5 SQUID magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the reagents were commercially available and used as purchased except that 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)ethane was synthesized according to the literature method. IR spectra as KBr pellets were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction measurements were recorded on a RIGAKU DMAX2500PC diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation. Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using a Quantum Design MPMS-XL5 SQUID magnetometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (0.061 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2-bis(imidazol-1′-yl)ethane (0.032 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid (0.041 g, 0.20 mmol), and NaOMe (0.022 g, 0.40 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (8 mL) and H2O (10 mL). The mixture was transferred to a 25 mL stainless-steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated to 165 °C automatically. The temperature was kept at 165 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 0.049 g, 52%, based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C18H18CdN4O4 (466.76): C 46.32, H 3.89, N 12.00; found: C 46.28, H 3.98, N 11.91. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3128(m), 1572 (vs), 1518 (s), 1417(w), 1392(vs), 1316(m), 1283(m), 1263 (m), 1235(s), 1108(s), 1086(vs), 1028(w), 935(s), 823(s), 764(m), 677(m), 652(s), 629(s), 559(w).

elements.content: Data collection of complexes 1−4 were conducted on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo−Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at low temperature (−100 °C). All of the four structures were solved by direct methods with the SHELX-97 programs and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL−97 program package. The positions of H atoms were generated geometrically (C−H bond fixed at 0.96 Å), assigned isotropic thermal parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent carbon atoms before the final cycle of refinement. Crystal data and structure determination summaries for 1−4 are listed in Table . The selected bond lengths and angles for the four complexes are listed in Table . Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) of 1−4 have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication. CCDC nos. 769597−769600.

On the basis of the synthetic viewpoint of coordination polymers, bime is a remarkable ligand to construct extended structures due to its simple coordination mode and strong coordination ability to metal ions. However, the assembly of the neutral N-donor ligands with metal ions is heavily dependent on the presence of counteranions to balance the positive charge. In order to simplify the effect of counteranions on the final results and to investigate the effect of flexible carboxylate ligands on bime conformations, we have introduced the aforementioned dicarboxylates (1,2-pda, 1,3-pda, 1,4-pda) as anionic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

On the basis of the synthetic viewpoint of coordination polymers, bime is a remarkable ligand to construct extended structures due to its simple coordination mode and strong coordination ability to metal ions. However, the assembly of the neutral N-donor ligands with metal ions is heavily dependent on the presence of counteranions to balance the positive charge. In order to simplify the effect of counteranions on the final results and to investigate the effect of flexible carboxylate ligands on bime conformations, we have introduced the aforementioned dicarboxylates (1,2-pda, 1,3-pda, 1,4-pda) as anionic ligands.

elements.content: All of the complexes were prepared under solvothermal conditions (V(CH3OH)/V(H2O) = 4:5). Complexes 1 and 2 were successfully isolated from the solvothermal reaction of bime, NaOMe, Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with 1,3-H2pda and 1,4-H2pda, respectively, while 3 and 4 were generated from the solvothermal reaction of bime, NaOMe, Co(NO3)2·6H2O with 1,2-H2pda and 1,4-H2pda, respectively. Complexes 1−4 are insoluble in most of common solvents, such as DMF, DMSO, water, methanol, dichloromethane, and hexane. It is interesting that the conformational isomers of bime were observed in the four complexes: anti-bime in 1 and 3, while gauche-bime in 2 and 4. As speculated, the orientation of carboxylates in 1,2-pda, 1,3-pda, and 1,4-pda plays a critical role in the occurrence of different conformations of bime in the four complexes.

elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses reveal that complexes 1 and 2 possess the two-dimensional layers, but their space groups, the coordination geometries of CdII ions, and the conformations of bime are entirely different.

elements.content: 1 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one CdII, two half of bime, and one deprotonated 1,3-pda. The CdII is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from two chelating carboxylate groups of different 1,3-pda and two nitrogen atoms from different bime. The average bond lengths of Cd−O and Cd−N are 2.381(4) and 2.263(3) Å, respectively, and the bond angle of N−Cd−N is 97.71(12)°. Interestingly, bime in 1 adopts an anti-conformation, and the two imidazolyl rings in bime are parallel. 1,3-pda bridges two CdII ions through two chelating carboxylate groups. So, the exobidentate bime connects the adjacent CdII ions into a one-dimensional chain, and the chain is further extended into a two-dimensional layer through the chelating carboxylate groups of 1,3-pda; the Cd···Cd distances separated by bime and 1,3-pda are 12.169 Å and 9.665 Å, respectively (Figure b,c).

elements.content: It is noteworthy that the two carboxylate groups of 1,3-pda are situated at the two sides of the benzene ring (Scheme a), and the dihedral angle between them is 76.8°; this kind of distortion between the long and flexible functional groups is mostly inclined to form helical structures. Therefore, 1 exhibits an interesting helical structure along the c axis (Figure d). The left- and right-handed helical units are present, which is consistent with the centric symmetry of the space group. All of the helical units are generated from one 1,3-pda and two bime alternatively connecting CdII with a pitch of 13.632 Å. In the helical chain, the anti-conformational bime can be defined as a linear linkage, while the flexible 1,3-pda can be considered as a distorted connector to formulate the helical structure.

elements.content: Complex 2 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pccn. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit consists of half CdII ion, half 1,4-pda, and half bime, and the CdII center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms from the chelating carboxylate groups of different 1,4-pda and two nitrogen atoms from different bime. The Cd−O bond lengths range from 2.277(3) to 2.479(2) Å, and the Cd−N bond length is 2.250(3) Å, which is similar to those in 1. The N−Cd−N bond angle of 101.71(15)° is larger than that in 1. 1,4-pda behaves as a bridge through two chelating carboxylate groups linking CdII centers into a one-dimensional chain; the bidentate bime further extends the adjacent chains into a two-dimensional layer, in which the metal···metal distances separated by 1,4-pda and bime are 12.494 Å and 7.896 Å, respectively (Figure b,c). Different from that in 1, the bime adopts a gauche-conformation, and the dihedral angle between two imidazolyl rings is 44.2°. The Cd···Cd distance (7.896 Å) across gauche-conformational bime in 2 is much shorter than that connected by anti-conformational bime in 1 (12.169 Å).

elements.content: As shown in Figure d, 2 also exhibits a helical framework. Both the left- and right-handed helical units are present, in which one bime and two 1,4-pda alternatively link CdII with a pitch of 17.900 Å. The two carboxylate groups of 1,4-pda situate in the two sides of the benzene ring (Scheme b), thereby the 1,4-pda may be regarded as a linear connector, while the gauche-conformational bime can be considered as a flexible connector and play an essential role in the formation of the helical structure, which is totally different from those in 1.

elements.content: Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P2/c. As depicted in Figure a, the CoII ion is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry; it is coordinated by two monodentate carboxylate oxygen atoms of different 1,2-pda and two nitrogen atoms of different bime. The Co−O and Co−N bond lengths are 1.9561(16) Å and 2.0331(17) Å, respectively, and the bond angles around CoII are from 92.19(8)° to 125.17(8)°. It should be emphasized that the tetrahedral environment about the CoII ion is rare in the cobalt-carboxylate complexes. In 3, bime adopts an anti-conformation and links the adjoining CoII ions into a one-dimensional chain; the metal···metal distance across it is 11.847 Å, which is slightly shorter than that in 1. The monodentate carboxylate groups of 1,2-pda further connect the adjoining chains into a two-dimensional layer, and the metal···metal distance across 1,2-pda is 8.165 Å (Figure b,c). The anti-conformational bime can be regarded as a linear linkage, while the twist of two carboxylate groups (the dihedral angle between them is 101.1°) in 1,2-pda (Scheme c) is of great benefit to construct helical structures. As shown in Figure d, one 1,2-pda and two bime alternatively connect CoII centers into left- and right-handed helical units with the helical pitch being 14.714 Å.

elements.content: Both 4 and 2 are isomorphous (Figure ). In 4, the 1,4-pda acts as a linear linker through two chelating carboxylate groups (Scheme b); the metal···metal across it is 12.255 Å, slightly shorter than that in 2. Different from the anti-conformational mode in 3, the bime adopts an gauche-conformation, and the dihedral angle between two imidazolyl rings is 40.9°, slightly smaller than that in 2 (44.2°); therefore, the metal···metal distance across it (7.753 Å) is shorter than that in 2 (7.896 Å). Similar to 2, 4 also is a helical structure, in which both left- and right-helical units are exhibited (). As those found in 1 and 2, the change of the position of two carboxylate groups in 1,2-pda and 1,4-pda results into the different metal···metal distances and different conformations of bime.

elements.content: As aforementioned, bime exhibits different conformations in four compounds, gauche-conformation in 1 and 3, anti-conformation in 2 and 4. As speculated, the change of the positions of carboxylate groups in the flexible dicarboxylate ligands may play an important role in the conformational preference of bime in the four helical coordination polymers. Owing to the different orientations of dicarboxylate groups, the metal···metal distances across them are slightly different. According to the basic concept of the crystals' growth, the structures with intense density packing and small inherent porosity would be generated and even more steady under thermodynamic control. Owing to the distinct increase of the distances across dicarboxylate ligands from 1 (9.665 Å) to 2 (12.494 Å), and 3 (8.165 Å) to 4 (12.255 Å), the metal···metal distances separated by bime would be decreased correspondingly. Moreover, the flexibility of the ethyl group in bime is a vital factor to connect neighboring metal ions. Thereby, the gauche-conformation of bime in 2 and 4 as well as anti-conformation in 1 and 3 were engendered in order to shorten the metal···metal distances, minimize the void cavities, and stabilize the framework by nature. As a result, the distinct decrease of the metal···metal distances across bime (7.896 Å in 2 and 12.169 Å in 1, and 7.753 Å in 4 and 11.847 Å in 3) were displayed.
elements.clean_text:
Conformational Isomers of bime in Complexes 1-4 

As aforementioned, bime exhibits different conformations in four compounds, gauche-conformation in 1 and 3, anti-conformation in 2 and 4. As speculated, the change of the positions of carboxylate groups in the flexible dicarboxylate ligands may play an important role in the conformational preference of bime in the four helical coordination polymers. Owing to the different orientations of dicarboxylate groups, the metal⋅⋅⋅metal distances across them are slightly different. According to the basic concept of the crystals' growth, the structures with intense density packing and small inherent porosity would be generated and even more steady under thermodynamic control. Owing to the distinct increase of the distances across dicarboxylate ligands from 1 (9.665 Å) to 2 (12.494 Å), and 3 (8.165 Å) to 4 (12.255 Å), the metal⋅⋅⋅metal distances separated by bime would be decreased correspondingly. Moreover, the flexibility of the ethyl group in bime is a vital factor to connect neighboring metal ions. Thereby, the gauche-conformation of bime in 2 and 4 as well as anti-conformation in 1 and 3 were engendered in order to shorten the metal⋅⋅⋅metal distances, minimize the void cavities, and stabilize the framework by nature. As a result, the distinct decrease of the metal⋅⋅⋅metal distances across bime (7.896 Å in 2 and 12.169 Å in 1, and 7.753 Å in 4 and 11.847 Å in 3) were displayed.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses of complexes 1−4 under nitrogen atmosphere were shown in Figure ; the stability temperatures of 1 and 2 are up to 605 and 586 °C, respectively, which are much higher than that of 3 (326 °C) and 4 (376 °C). A sharp weight loss over these temperatures was observed in 1−4. This suggested that the organic ligands began to combust and the frameworks were thus collapsed.

Thermogravimetric Analyses

elements.content: The emission spectra of complexes 1−2 in the solid state at room temperature have been shown in Figure . It can be seen that the intense broad photoluminescence emission at 387 nm for 1 and 389 nm for 2, respectively, are exhibited. The emission of 1 and 2 are assigned as ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT), and the similar emission may be due to σ-donation from the similar coordination environments of the CdII centers in 1 and 2.

Fluorescent Properties in Complexes 1 and 2

It can be seen that the intense broad photoluminescence emission at 387 nm for 1 and 389 nm for 2, respectively, are exhibited. The emission of 1 and 2 are assigned as ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT), and the similar emission may be due to σ-donation from the similar coordination environments of the CdII centers in 1 and 2.

elements.content: Magnetic measurements were performed on the samples containing a collection of very small block single crystals with random orientation. Complexes 3 and 4 have similar magnetic behaviors. Both the temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 3 and 4 were investigated in the temperature range 2−300 K (Figure ). The plots of χm −1 versus T obey the Curie−Weiss law [χm = C/(T − θ)], the best fit gives C = 2.41 cm3 mol−1 K and θ = −0.79 K, the C value corresponds to g = 2.27 for 3 (Figure a), and C = 3.25 cm3 mol−1 K, θ = −15.46 K, g = 2.63 for 4 (Figure b). The negative values of θ suggest similar weak antiferromagnetic coupling between CoII centers in 3 and 4.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties in Complexes 3 and 4 

Magnetic measurements were performed on the samples containing a collection of very small block single crystals with random orientation. Complexes 3 and 4 have similar magnetic behaviors. Both the temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 3 and 4 were investigated in the temperature range 2-300 K (Figure ). The plots of χm -1 versus T obey the Curie-Weiss law [χm = C/(T - θ)], the best fit gives C = 2.41 cm3 mol-1 K and θ = -0.79 K, the C value corresponds to g = 2.27 for 3 (Figure a), and C = 3.25 cm3 mol-1 K, θ = -15.46 K, g = 2.63 for 4 (Figure b). The negative values of θ suggest similar weak antiferromagnetic coupling between CoII centers in 3 and 4.

elements.content: Four cadmium and cobalt helical coordination polymers from flexible exobidenate imidazolyl ligand and flexible dicarboxylate ligands have been successfully synthesized and characterized. bime adopts anti-conformation in 1 and 3, while gauche-conformation of bime is observed in 2 and 4. The investigation reveals that conformational preference of bime is heavily dependent on the use of flexible dicarboxylate ligands with different positions of dicarboxylate groups and different metal···metal distances connected by dicarboxylate groups. On the other hand, the results also show that the use of flexible ligands is a feasible route to synthesize and formulate helical structures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Four cadmium and cobalt helical coordination polymers from flexible exobidenate imidazolyl ligand and flexible dicarboxylate ligands have been successfully synthesized and characterized. bime adopts anti-conformation in 1 and 3, while gauche-conformation of bime is observed in 2 and 4. The investigation reveals that conformational preference of bime is heavily dependent on the use of flexible dicarboxylate ligands with different positions of dicarboxylate groups and different metal⋅⋅⋅metal distances connected by dicarboxylate groups. On the other hand, the results also show that the use of flexible ligands is a feasible route to synthesize and formulate helical structures.

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (0.061 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,2-bis(imidazol-1'-yl)ethane (0.032 g, 0.20 mmol), 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid (0.041 g, 0.20 mmol), and NaOMe (0.022 g, 0.40 mmol) was dissolved in CH3OH (8 mL) and H2O (10 mL). The mixture was transferred to a 25 mL stainless-steel reactor with Teflon liner and heated to 165 °C automatically. The temperature was kept at 165 °C for 4 days and cooled to room temperature during 24 h. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained (yield: 0.049 g, 52%, based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C18H18CdN4O4 (466.76): C 46.32, H 3.89, N 12.00; found: C 46.28, H 3.98, N 11.91. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3128(m), 1572 (vs), 1518 (s), 1417(w), 1392(vs), 1316(m), 1283(m), 1263 (m), 1235(s), 1108(s), 1086(vs), 1028(w), 935(s), 823(s), 764(m), 677(m), 652(s), 629(s), 559(w).

Synthesis of [Cd(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n  (2)

The procedures were similar to the synthesis of 1 except that 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid was replaced by 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.041 g, 0.20 mmol). Colorless crystals of 2 were obtained (yield: 0.039 g, 42% based on Cd). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C9H9Cd0.5N2O2 (233.38): C 46.32, H 3.89, N 12.00; found: C 46.30, H 3.94, N 11.89. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3128(m), 3102(m), 2906(w), 1563(vs), 1527(m), 1420(s), 1389(vs), 1280(m), 1244(s), 1204(w), 1106(vs), 1089(s), 1028(w), 938(s), 860(s), 784(w), 762(s), 703(s), 655(s), 627(m), 585(w), 515(w), 487(m), 439(m).

Synthesis of [Co(anti-bime)(1,2-pda)] n  (3)

The procedures were similar to the synthesis of 1 except that 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O were replaced by 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid (0.041 g, 0.20 mmol) and Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.060 g, 0.20 mmol), respectively. Deep red crystals of 3 were obtained (yield: 0.042 g, 51% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C18H18CoN4O4 (413.30): C 52.31, H 4.39, N 13.56; found: C 52.19, H 4.25, N 13.44. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3152(m), 1554(vs), 1465(vs), 1380(s), 1298(m), 1264(m), 1238(w), 1115(m), 1091(m), 1002(w), 969(w), 862(w), 785(m), 749(w), 720(s), 656(w).

Synthesis of [Co(gauche-bime)(1,4-pda)] n  (4)

The procedures were similar to the synthesis of 3 except that 1,3-phenylenediacetic acid was replaced by 1,4-phenylenediacetic acid (0.041 g, 0.20 mmol). Purple crystals of 4 were obtained (yield: 0.035 g, 43% based on Co). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C18H18CoN4O4 (413.30): C 52.31, H 4.39, N 13.56; found: C 52.27, H 4.30, N 13.52. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3415(bs), 1545(vs), 1470(s), 1378(vs), 1305(w), 1269(m), 1212(w), 1094(m), 992(w), 971(w), 792(s), 726(s), 514(w).

Thermogravimetric analyses of complexes 1−4 under nitrogen atmosphere were shown in Figure ; the stability temperatures of 1 and 2 are up to 605 and 586 °C, respectively, which are much higher than that of 3 (326 °C) and 4 (376 °C). A sharp weight loss over these temperatures was observed in 1−4. This suggested that the organic ligands began to combust and the frameworks were thus collapsed.

Fluorescent Properties in Complexes <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

The emission spectra of complexes 1−2 in the solid state at room temperature have been shown in Figure . It can be seen that the intense broad photoluminescence emission at 387 nm for 1 and 389 nm for 2, respectively, are exhibited. The emission of 1 and 2 are assigned as ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT), and the similar emission may be due to σ-donation from the similar coordination environments of the CdII centers in 1 and 2.

Magnetic Properties in Complexes <bold>3</bold> and <bold>4</bold>

Magnetic measurements were performed on the samples containing a collection of very small block single crystals with random orientation. Complexes 3 and 4 have similar magnetic behaviors. Both the temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 3 and 4 were investigated in the temperature range 2−300 K (Figure ). The plots of χm −1 versus T obey the Curie−Weiss law [χm = C/(T − θ)], the best fit gives C = 2.41 cm3 mol−1 K and θ = −0.79 K, the C value corresponds to g = 2.27 for 3 (Figure a), and C = 3.25 cm3 mol−1 K, θ = −15.46 K, g = 2.63 for 4 (Figure b). The negative values of θ suggest similar weak antiferromagnetic coupling between CoII centers in 3 and 4.
